title: Supreme Court health care ruling: 6 takeaways
content:
Remember when all the pundits said the mandate was 'toast ' ? Not so much . 6 SCOTUS takeaways
For sheer drama , the Supreme Court ’ s cliffhanger decision on President Barack Obama ’ s health care law didn ’ t disappoint .
The landmark legislation survived through a 5-4 ruling that almost no one predicted .
Here are six takeaways on the blockbuster ending to the court ’ s term .
On Thursday , Chief Justice John Roberts made history — and not simply by providing the pivotal vote to uphold the health care law .
He did something he ’ s never done in his seven years on the court : vote with the court ’ s liberal justices in a 5-4 decision .
Sure , Roberts ’ s rationale differed somewhat from that of his liberal colleagues . He said the tax aspect of the individual mandate rendered it constitutional , while they thought it could also be justified under the Commerce Clause . But a win is a win , and Roberts ’ s vote gave Obama ’ s team a coveted victory .
The chief justice ’ s move triggered an angry reaction from his fellow conservatives on the court . They didn ’ t single him out but left no confusion about their view that he had distorted and abandoned conservative legal principles .
“ The Court regards its strained statutory interpretation as judicial modesty . It is not . It amounts instead to a vast judicial overreaching , ” the dissenting justices wrote in their joint opinion .
Some on the right are painting Roberts as a turncoat , but his basic loyalty to the conservative cause is hard to challenge . On Monday , Roberts was delivering a strident , classically conservative dissent in a case declaring that minors could not be sentenced to life in prison .
In statistical terms , the chief justice ’ s decision on the health care law was an aberration . But an aberration on the court ’ s most politically significant case in a generation is certain to alter liberals ’ and conservatives ’ views of Roberts for good .
In decision after decision for a decade , Justice Anthony Kennedy has provided the swing vote that sometimes allowed the court ’ s liberal justices to prevail over its conservative majority .
Though he generally sides with his fellow Republican appointees , supporters of the health care law considered Kennedy a good prospect to favor its constitutionality . In recent years , the Reagan appointee lined up 5-4 with liberals to ban capital punishment for murders committed by minors , allow appeals by Guantanamo prisoners and permit colleges to require that student groups be open to gays and lesbians .
But in the health care case , not only did Kennedy side with the conservatives , he represented them by reading their views in the courtroom .
Kennedy ’ s skepticism about the individual mandate was foreshadowed during oral arguments in the case , when he proved far more hostile to the health care law than many analysts predicted .
” I understand that we must presume laws are constitutional , but , even so , when you are changing the relation of the individual to the government in this … do you not have a heavy burden of justification to show authorization under the Constitution ? ” Kennedy said . “ The government is saying that the federal government has a duty to tell the individual citizen that it must act , and that is different from what we have in previous cases . ”
The tax that ’ s not a tax : sleeper argument carries the day
None of the lower court judges who heard cases challenging the individual mandate bought the federal government ’ s argument that it is constitutional under Congress ’ s power to tax . It ’ s not called a tax in the law , they said , and President Barack Obama went on television and said it wasn ’ t a tax , too .

Remember when all the pundits said the mandate was 'toast'? Not so much. 6 SCOTUS takeaways

For sheer drama, the Supreme Court’s cliffhanger decision on President Barack Obama’s health care law didn’t disappoint.

The landmark legislation survived through a 5-4 ruling that almost no one predicted.

Here are six takeaways on the blockbuster ending to the court’s term.

( Also on POLITICO: SCOTUS ruling shakes up 2012 race)

Roberts bucks personal history

On Thursday, Chief Justice John Roberts made history — and not simply by providing the pivotal vote to uphold the health care law.

He did something he’s never done in his seven years on the court: vote with the court’s liberal justices in a 5-4 decision.

Sure, Roberts’s rationale differed somewhat from that of his liberal colleagues. He said the tax aspect of the individual mandate rendered it constitutional, while they thought it could also be justified under the Commerce Clause. But a win is a win, and Roberts’s vote gave Obama’s team a coveted victory.

The chief justice’s move triggered an angry reaction from his fellow conservatives on the court. They didn’t single him out but left no confusion about their view that he had distorted and abandoned conservative legal principles.

“The Court regards its strained statutory interpretation as judicial modesty. It is not. It amounts instead to a vast judicial overreaching,” the dissenting justices wrote in their joint opinion.

Some on the right are painting Roberts as a turncoat, but his basic loyalty to the conservative cause is hard to challenge. On Monday, Roberts was delivering a strident, classically conservative dissent in a case declaring that minors could not be sentenced to life in prison.

In statistical terms, the chief justice’s decision on the health care law was an aberration. But an aberration on the court’s most politically significant case in a generation is certain to alter liberals’ and conservatives’ views of Roberts for good.

( Also on POLITICO: Republicans: Et tu, Roberts?)

Kennedy: the swing vote unswung

In decision after decision for a decade, Justice Anthony Kennedy has provided the swing vote that sometimes allowed the court’s liberal justices to prevail over its conservative majority.

Not so Thursday.

Though he generally sides with his fellow Republican appointees, supporters of the health care law considered Kennedy a good prospect to favor its constitutionality. In recent years, the Reagan appointee lined up 5-4 with liberals to ban capital punishment for murders committed by minors, allow appeals by Guantanamo prisoners and permit colleges to require that student groups be open to gays and lesbians.

But in the health care case, not only did Kennedy side with the conservatives, he represented them by reading their views in the courtroom.

Kennedy’s skepticism about the individual mandate was foreshadowed during oral arguments in the case, when he proved far more hostile to the health care law than many analysts predicted.

”I understand that we must presume laws are constitutional, but, even so, when you are changing the relation of the individual to the government in this … do you not have a heavy burden of justification to show authorization under the Constitution?” Kennedy said. “The government is saying that the federal government has a duty to tell the individual citizen that it must act, and that is different from what we have in previous cases.”

The tax that’s not a tax: sleeper argument carries the day

None of the lower court judges who heard cases challenging the individual mandate bought the federal government’s argument that it is constitutional under Congress’s power to tax. It’s not called a tax in the law, they said, and President Barack Obama went on television and said it wasn’t a tax, too.
